chapters.name: Moral Realism: Do Moral Facts Exist?
topics: How do moral realists defend the claim that 'torture is wrong' is objectively true — as true as 'water is H₂O' — independent of what any person, culture, or society believes, and where do these moral facts come from if not from God, nature, or human agreement?

What is Cornell realism (Richard Boyd, Nicholas Sturgeon) — the view that moral properties are natural properties, that 'goodness' is as real as 'redness,' discoverable through observation — and why did critics object that this collapses the distinction between facts and values?

How did Derek Parfit defend moral realism in 'On What Matters' (2011) — arguing that Kantians, consequentialists, and contractualists are 'climbing the same mountain from different sides' and converge on the same objective truths — and why did some philosophers find this convergence thesis too convenient?

What is the Euthyphro dilemma — does God command something because it is good, or is it good because God commands it? — and why has this 2,400-year-old puzzle shown that divine command theory cannot ground moral realism?

How does the argument from disagreement challenge moral realism — if moral facts exist, why do cultures disagree about female circumcision, capital punishment, and eating meat? — and how do realists respond (moral disagreement no more disproves moral facts than scientific disagreement disproves scientific facts)?

chapters.name: Moral Anti-Realism: Error Theory and Expressivism
topics: What is J.L. Mackie's error theory — argued in 'Ethics: Inventing Right and Wrong' (1977), that all moral statements are literally false because there are no moral facts, that morality is a useful fiction humanity invented — and how did this unflinching nihilism force philosophers to either refute it or accept its consequences?

How does expressivism (A.J. Ayer, Simon Blackburn) offer a different anti-realist position — arguing that moral statements don't describe facts but express attitudes ('murder is wrong' means 'boo to murder!') — and why did the 'Frege-Geach problem' nearly destroy this theory before Blackburn's quasi-realism rescued it?

What is moral fictionalism — the view that moral language is literally false (like error theory says) but useful to maintain (like Santa Claus for children) — and can a society function on moral beliefs its smartest members know to be fictions?

How did Nietzsche anticipate anti-realism — arguing that moral values are human creations reflecting power relations, that 'there are no moral facts' — and why did his genealogical approach (asking where moral beliefs come from rather than whether they're true) become the dominant method of anti-realist ethics?

What practical difference does the realism/anti-realism debate make — if morality is invented rather than discovered, does that mean anything goes, or can constructed moral systems be better or worse without being objectively true?

chapters.name: The Is-Ought Problem: Hume's Guillotine
topics: What did Hume observe in 'A Treatise of Human Nature' (1739) — that moral philosophers constantly slide from 'is' statements (descriptions of how things are) to 'ought' statements (prescriptions for how things should be) without justifying the transition — and why has this 'guillotine' resisted every attempt to bridge it?

How did G.E. Moore's 'naturalistic fallacy' (1903) reinforce the is-ought gap — arguing that 'good' cannot be defined in terms of any natural property (pleasure, evolutionary fitness, social harmony) because we can always meaningfully ask 'but is that really good?' — and is Moore's 'open question argument' still persuasive?

How have evolutionary ethicists attempted to derive ought from is — arguing that moral instincts evolved because they promoted survival, that cooperation, fairness, and empathy are naturally selected behaviors — and why did philosophers from Moore to Kitcher argue this commits the naturalistic fallacy?

What did Philippa Foot argue in 'Natural Goodness' (2001) — that virtues are natural excellences of the human species the way sharp claws are natural excellences of a tiger — and why does this neo-Aristotelian naturalism claim to bridge the is-ought gap without committing the naturalistic fallacy?

Why has Sam Harris's 'The Moral Landscape' (2010) — arguing that science can determine moral values because well-being is objectively measurable — been rejected by virtually every professional philosopher, and what does this rejection reveal about the enduring power of Hume's guillotine?

chapters.name: Moral Relativism: Is Morality Just Culture?
topics: Why does moral relativism — the view that moral truths vary between cultures and that no universal standard exists — appeal to most ordinary people while being rejected by most professional philosophers?

How did anthropologists like Franz Boas and Ruth Benedict document radical moral diversity across cultures — infanticide, cannibalism, polygamy, honor killing — and why did they argue that judging other cultures by Western standards is ethnocentric imperialism?

What is the strongest argument against relativism — that it makes it impossible to criticize practices like slavery, genocide, or female genital cutting, because if morality is culturally determined, then Nazi Germany's morality was 'right for them' — and can relativists escape this conclusion?

How does Gilbert Harman's moral relativism differ from cultural relativism — arguing that moral judgments are relative not to cultures but to agreements among individuals, creating a more sophisticated position that still faces the 'no criticism' problem?

Why did the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948) implicitly reject moral relativism — asserting that certain rights are universal regardless of cultural context — and how do Asian values debates, Islamic critiques, and postcolonial theory challenge this claim to universality?

chapters.name: Moral Psychology: Why Do Humans Have Morality at All?
topics: How did Jonathan Haidt's moral foundations theory identify six innate moral intuitions — care/harm, fairness/cheating, loyalty/betrayal, authority/subversion, sanctity/degradation, liberty/oppression — and why did this research show that liberals and conservatives emphasize different foundations?

What did the trolley problem reveal under fMRI scanning — Joshua Greene's finding that impersonal dilemmas activate utilitarian reasoning (prefrontal cortex) while personal dilemmas activate emotional responses (amygdala) — and does neuroscience support utilitarianism, deontology, or neither?

How did Frans de Waal's research on primate morality — chimpanzees showing empathy, fairness, and reciprocity — challenge the assumption that morality requires language, culture, or divine gift, and what did the capuchin 'unfairness' experiment (rejecting unequal cucumber-versus-grape payments) demonstrate?

What is the psychopath problem for moral philosophy — psychopaths understand moral rules but feel no emotional motivation to follow them — and what does this reveal about whether morality is grounded in reason (Kant) or sentiment (Hume)?

How did Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development — from obedience (stage 1) through social conformity (stages 3-4) to universal principles (stage 6) — attempt to show that moral reasoning progresses toward objectivity, and why did Carol Gilligan criticize his framework as biased toward male moral reasoning?

chapters.name: Evolution and Morality: Can Darwin Explain Ethics?
topics: How did Darwin himself address the evolution of morality — arguing in 'The Descent of Man' (1871) that social instincts, sympathy, and the capacity for moral judgment evolved because they promoted group survival — and why was this one of his most controversial claims?

What is the problem of altruism for evolutionary theory — if natural selection favors self-interested behavior, why do humans (and other animals) sacrifice for others? — and how did kin selection (Hamilton), reciprocal altruism (Trivers), and group selection (Sober and Wilson) attempt to solve it?

How did evolutionary debunking arguments (Sharon Street, Richard Joyce) use Darwin against moral realism — arguing that if our moral beliefs evolved to promote survival rather than track truth, we have no reason to trust them — and how did moral realists respond?

What is the 'moral sense' hypothesis — that evolution equipped humans with emotional responses (guilt, shame, indignation, empathy) that function as a moral compass — and why did Jesse Prinz argue that these emotions are too culturally variable to count as a universal moral sense?

Can evolutionary ethics avoid the naturalistic fallacy — deriving what we ought to do from what evolution has programmed us to feel — or does every attempt to ground morality in biology commit the same error that Hume identified in 1739?

chapters.name: Moral Language: What Do Moral Words Mean?
topics: What did A.J. Ayer's emotivism claim — that 'stealing is wrong' has no factual content but merely expresses disapproval, like saying 'stealing — boo!' — and why did the logical positivists consider moral language literally meaningless?

How did R.M. Hare's prescriptivism improve on emotivism — arguing that moral statements are not just expressions of emotion but universal prescriptions ('no one should steal') — and why did this make moral language more like commanding than describing?

What is the 'thick concepts' problem — words like 'cruel,' 'courageous,' and 'generous' that seem simultaneously descriptive and evaluative — and why did Bernard Williams argue that these concepts show the fact/value distinction is not as clean as philosophers assumed?

How did John Searle attempt to derive an 'ought' from an 'is' using the concept of promising — if I promise to pay you, I ought to pay you, deriving obligation from the social institution of promising — and why did most philosophers remain unconvinced?

What does the persistence of moral disagreement reveal about moral language — do we disagree because we mean different things by 'good' (semantic problem), because we have different evidence (epistemic problem), or because there are no moral facts to agree about (ontological problem)?

chapters.name: Meta-Ethics in Practice: Why These Questions Matter
topics: How does the meta-ethical debate affect real-world moral arguments — if moral realism is true, then human rights are discovered; if anti-realism is true, they are invented — and does it matter for practice whether rights are 'real' or just extremely useful fictions?

Why did moral constructivism (Christine Korsgaard, T.M. Scanlon) offer a middle path — arguing that morality is neither discovered in nature nor merely expressed as emotion, but constructed through practical reasoning — and can constructed morality be genuinely binding?

How does meta-ethics inform debates about AI alignment — if we want artificial intelligence to be 'moral,' we first need to know what morality is: a set of facts to program, a set of preferences to optimize, or a set of practices to learn?

What did Derek Parfit mean when he said meta-ethics is 'the most important issue in philosophy' — because if there are no objective moral truths, then nothing really matters, and the entire enterprise of ethics is a sophisticated game — and did his lifelong attempt to prove moral realism succeed?

Why has meta-ethics failed to produce consensus after 2,500 years of argument — moral realism, anti-realism, relativism, constructivism, and naturalism all retain serious defenders — and does this persistent disagreement itself constitute evidence for or against the existence of moral truth?
